para.sentence: Let s^{2}(t) be a cubic or quartic polynomial in t with simple zeros, and let r(s,t) be a rational function of s and t containing at least one odd power of s.
Then \int r(s,t)\mathrm{d}t is called an elliptic integral.

Because s^{2} is a polynomial, we have r(s,t)=\frac{(p_{1}+p_{2}s)(p_{3}-p_{4}s)s}{(p_{3}+p_{4}s)(p_{3}-p_{4}s)s}= \frac{\rho}{s}+\sigma, where p_{j} is a polynomial in t while \rho and \sigma are rational functions of t.
Thus the elliptic part of (19.2.1) is \int\frac{\rho(t)}{s(t)}\mathrm{d}t.

Assume 1-{\sin^{2}}\phi\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0] and 1-k^{2}{\sin^{2}}\phi\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0] , except that one of them may be 0, and 1-\alpha^{2}{\sin^{2}}\phi\in\mathbb{C}\setminus\{0\}.

Then F\left(\phi,k\right)=\int_{0}^{\phi}\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\sqrt{1-k^{2}{\sin ^{2}}\theta}}=\int_{0}^{\sin\phi}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}\sqrt{1-k^{2 }t^{2}}}, , E\left(\phi,k\right)=\int_{0}^{\phi}\sqrt{1-k^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta}\mathrm{d} \theta\\ =\int_{0}^{\sin\phi}\frac{\sqrt{1-k^{2}t^{2}}}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}\mathrm{d}t.

D\left(\phi,k\right)=\int_{0}^{\phi}\frac{{\sin^{2}}\theta\mathrm{d}\theta}{ \sqrt{1-k^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta}}=\int_{0}^{\sin\phi}\frac{t^{2}\mathrm{d}t}{ \sqrt{1-t^{2}}\sqrt{1-k^{2}t^{2}}}=(F\left(\phi,k\right)-E\left(\phi,k\right)) /k^{2}.

\Pi\left(\phi,\alpha^{2},k\right)=\int_{0}^{\phi}\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\sqrt {1-k^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta}(1-\alpha^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta)}=\int_{0}^{\sin\phi} \frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}\sqrt{1-k^{2}t^{2}}(1-\alpha^{2}t^{2})}.
The paths of integration are the line segments connecting the limits of integration.

The integral for E\left(\phi,k\right) is well defined if k^{2}={\sin^{2}}\phi=1 , and the Cauchy principal value (§1.4(v)) of \Pi\left(\phi,\alpha^{2},k\right) is taken if 1-\alpha^{2}{\sin^{2}}\phi vanishes at an interior point of the integration path.
Also, if k^{2} and \alpha^{2} are real, then \Pi\left(\phi,\alpha^{2},k\right) is called a circular orhyperbolic case according as \alpha^{2}(\alpha^{2}-k^{2})(\alpha^{2}-1) is negative or positive.
The circular and hyperbolic cases alternate in the four intervals of the real line separated by the points \alpha^{2}=0,k^{2},1.

The cases with \phi=\pi/2 are the complete integrals: K\left(k\right)=F\left(\pi/2,k\right),E\left(k\right)=E\left(\pi/2,k\right),D\left(k\right)=D\left(\pi/2,k\right)=(K\left(k\right)-E\left(k\right))/k^{2},\Pi\left(\alpha^{2},k\right)=\Pi\left(\pi/2,\alpha^{2},k\right), {K^{\prime}}\left(k\right)=K\left(k^{\prime}\right),{E^{\prime}}\left(k\right)=E\left(k^{\prime}\right),k^{\prime}=\sqrt{1-k^{2}}.

If m is an integer, then F\left(m\pi\pm\phi,k\right)=2mK\left(k\right)\pm F\left(\phi,k\right),E\left(m\pi\pm\phi,k\right)=2mE\left(k\right)\pm E\left(\phi,k\right),D\left(m\pi\pm\phi,k\right)=2mD\left(k\right)\pm D\left(\phi,k\right).
Bulirsch’s integrals are linear combinations of Legendre’s integrals that arechosen to facilitate computational application of Bartky’s transformation (Bartky (1938)).

Two are defined by \mathrm{cel}\left(k_{c},p,a,b\right)=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{a{\cos^{2}}\theta+b {\sin^{2}}\theta}{{\cos^{2}}\theta+p{\sin^{2}}\theta}\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{ \sqrt{{\cos^{2}}\theta+k_{c}^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta}}, \mathrm{el2}\left(x,k_{c},a,b\right)=\int_{0}^{\operatorname{arctan}x}\frac{a+ b{\tan^{2}}\theta}{\sqrt{(1+{\tan^{2}}\theta)(1+k_{c}^{2}{\tan^{2}}\theta)}} \mathrm{d}\theta.
Here a,b,p are real parameters, and k_{c} and x are real orcomplex variables, with p\neq 0 , k_{c}\neq 0.
If -\infty<p<0 , then the integral in (19.2.11) is a Cauchy principal value.

With k_{c}=k^{\prime},p=1-\alpha^{2},x=\tan\phi, special cases include K\left(k\right)=\mathrm{cel}\left(k_{c},1,1,1\right),E\left(k\right)=\mathrm{cel}\left(k_{c},1,1,k_{c}^{2}\right),D\left(k\right)=\mathrm{cel}\left(k_{c},1,0,1\right),(E\left(k\right)-{k^{\prime}}^{2}K\left(k\right))/k^{2}=\mathrm{cel}\left(k_{c },1,1,0\right),\Pi\left(\alpha^{2},k\right)=\mathrm{cel}\left(k_{c},p,1,1\right), and F\left(\phi,k\right)=\mathrm{el1}\left(x,k_{c}\right)=\mathrm{el2}\left(x,k_{c },1,1\right),E\left(\phi,k\right)=\mathrm{el2}\left(x,k_{c},1,k_{c}^{2}\right),D\left(\phi,k\right)=\mathrm{el2}\left(x,k_{c},0,1\right).
The integrals are complete if x=\infty.
If 1<k\leq 1/\sin\phi , then k_{c} is pure imaginary.

Lastly, corresponding to Legendre’s incomplete integral of the third kind we have \mathrm{el3}\left(x,k_{c},p\right)=\int_{0}^{\operatorname{arctan}x}\frac{ \mathrm{d}\theta}{({\cos^{2}}\theta+p{\sin^{2}}\theta)\sqrt{{\cos^{2}}\theta+k _{c}^{2}{\sin^{2}}\theta}}=\Pi\left(\operatorname{arctan}x,1-p,k\right), if x^{2}\neq-1/p.
Let x\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0) and y\in\mathbb{C}\setminus\{0\}.
We define R_{C}\left(x,y\right)=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{t+x }(t+y)}, where the Cauchy principal value is taken if y<0.

Formulas involving \Pi\left(\phi,\alpha^{2},k\right) that are customarily different for circular cases, ordinary hyperbolic cases, and (hyperbolic) Cauchy principal values, are united in a single formula by using R_{C}\left(x,y\right).
In (19.2.18)–(19.2.22) the inverse trigonometric and hyperbolic functions assume their principal values (§§4.23(ii)and4.37(ii)).

When x and y are positive, R_{C}\left(x,y\right) is an inverse circular function if x<y and an inverse hyperbolic function (or logarithm) if x>y : R_{C}\left(x,y\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{y-x}}\operatorname{arctan}\sqrt{\frac{y-x }{x}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{y-x}}\operatorname{arccos}\sqrt{x/y}, if 0\leq x<y, R_{C}\left(x,y\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x-y}}\operatorname{arctanh}\sqrt{\frac{x- y}{x}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x-y}}\ln\frac{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x-y}}{\sqrt{y}}, if 0<y<x.

The Cauchy principal value is hyperbolic: R_{C}\left(x,y\right)=\sqrt{\frac{x}{x-y}}R_{C}\left(x-y,-y\right)=\frac{1}{ \sqrt{x-y}}\operatorname{arctanh}\sqrt{\frac{x}{x-y}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x-y}}\ln \frac{\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x-y}}{\sqrt{-y}}, if y<0\leq x.
For the special cases of R_{C}\left(x,x\right) and R_{C}\left(0,y\right) see (19.6.15).

If the line segment with endpoints x and y lies in \mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0] , then R_{C}\left(x,y\right)=\int_{0}^{1}(v^{2}x+(1-v^{2})y)^{-1/2}\mathrm{d}v, R_{C}\left(x,y\right)=\frac{2}{\pi}\int_{0}^{\pi/2}R_{C}\left(y,x{\cos^{2}} \theta+y{\sin^{2}}\theta\right)\mathrm{d}\theta.
